channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Swedish King Says His Country "Failed" Pandemic Response
item.description: Yesterday, Sweden's King Carl XVI Gustaf said his country "failed" its pandemic response.     Refresher: While other countries enacted strict lockdowns when the pandemic began, Sweden gambled on an open economy and voluntary guidelines, with the goal of eventually reaching herd immunity. If it's approved, Swedish healthcare workers get dibs around Christmas.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Japanese Appliance Startup Pops 88% in Public Market Debut
item.description: Bottom line: There wasn't a market for high-end toasters until Balmuda showed what was possible. It comes with a little teaspoon of water, which helps seal in moisture. That sexy little oven above will set you back $224, and Balmuda’s “The Gohan” rice cooker costs $400.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Massachusetts Takes Aim at Robinhood for Failing to Protect its Customers
item.description: Yesterday, Massachusetts securities regulators filed a complaint against the popular stock trading platform Robinhood for prioritizing “its revenue over the best interest of its customers,” according to documents reviewed by the WSJ.     Robinhood’s easy-to-navigate platform has attracted over 13 million insanely active traders.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: U.S. Labels Vietnam, Switzerland Currency Manipulators
item.description: Yesterday, the U.S. Treasury labeled the European country and Vietnam currency manipulators.   Why it matters: Labeling countries as currency manipulators is rarer than a Federer two-handed backhand, and it reflects the tougher trade stance taken by the Trump administration toward both allies and rivals.   What is currency manipulation?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Texas Attorney General Leads Antitrust Suit Against Google Focusing on its Ad Business
item.description: The suit claims that Google is the Joey Chestnut to the digital advertising industry's plate of hot dogs.   Yesterday, a group of state attorneys general led by Texas said they're taking legal action against Google for, you guessed it, engaging in anticompetitive practices.   Zoom out: If this feels like déjà sue, you’d be correct.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Second Stimulus Measure is Reportedly Back on the Table. Could it Finally Happen?
item.description: Sophie Turner = a second stimulus package.   But if there are any snags, votes could spill into the weekend.   Looking ahead... At the conclusion of the Fed's two-day meeting, the central bank said it will keep interest rates near zero and keep buying bonds until the U.S. reaches full employment and inflation settles at 2%.   Fed Chair Jerome Powell is trying to do his part to juice the economy. the government will run out of money at midnight on Friday without a spending bill.   Also...
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Massachusetts Takes Aim at Robinhood for Failing to Protect its Customers
item.description: Robinhood’s easy-to-navigate platform has attracted over 13 million insanely active traders. Yesterday, Massachusetts securities regulators filed a complaint against the popular stock trading platform Robinhood for prioritizing “its revenue over the best interest of its customers,” according to documents reviewed by the WSJ.

item.title: U.S. Labels Vietnam, Switzerland Currency Manipulators
item.description: Yesterday, the U.S. Treasury labeled the European country and Vietnam currency manipulators. It’s when governments try to tilt the winds of trade in their favor by illegally tinkering with their currency. But the Swiss government doesn't want it to rise too much.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Texas Attorney General Leads Antitrust Suit Against Google Focusing on its Ad Business
item.description: The suit claims that Google is the Joey Chestnut to the digital advertising industry's plate of hotdogs.   Yesterday, a group of state attorneys general led by Texas said they're taking legal action against Google for, you guessed it, engaging in anticompetitive practices.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Brew’s Bookshelf: Holiday Gift Guide
item.description: Henry Stockwell, copywriter: E: A Novel by Matt Beaumont This novel is really just a collection of fake emails from a fictional London ad agency at the start of the 21st century, when I guess ad agencies still operated somewhat like Mad Men?   Milo Booke, product manager: One Billion Americans by Matthew Yglesias  Yglesias lays out a vision of an America that reorients its policies and culture toward growing our population massively, giving us more economic and diplomatic heft and influence in a world of other ascendant global powers.   Mainly, this book takes anime seriously as a “media success story,” just as companies like Netflix are starting to do.   Eliza Carter, daily newsletter writer: Billion Dollar Loser by Reeves Wiedeman  You know the rise and fall of WeWork was nuts. If you’re a movie buff, this is a must read. Hayden Field, Emerging Tech Brew writer: Uncanny Valley by Anna Wiener  A beautifully-written memoir about the author’s move from the New York publishing industry to the Silicon Valley tech world. This is the main question asked throughout the book and I believe that it guides the reader to find that answer. Buy it here. How much of it is what we really know and want versus what’s taught to us?   Kate Noel, VP & head of people ops: Untamed by Glennon Doyle  A memoir that really peels back the layers of what it means to be a woman, mother, and friend in today’s society. But this up-close account from NYMag reporter Reeves Wiedeman reveals the nuttery to be even nuttier than you imagined.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Nickelodeon to Air NFL Wild Card Game
item.description: Food for thought: Who makes your all-Nickelodeon football roster?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: President-elect Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
item.description: Buttigieg endorsed Biden and helped him raise money, despite Biden having run an ad mocking Buttigieg's relatively paltry experience.     More broadly, Buttigieg will manage a nearly $90 billion budget, plus oversee the agencies that regulate railroads, trucking, and aviation.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: EU Unveils Regulations Targeting Big Tech
item.description: The walls are closing in This week, the FTC ordered top U.S. tech companies to explain their user data practices, China fined its own tech leaders Alibaba and Tencent over antitrust violations, and the UK proposed fines of up to 10% of global revenue if tech giants don't remove illegal content.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Anna Wintour Promoted at Condé Nast, Again
item.description: The backstory: Wintour became U.S. Vogue editor in 1988, then added the "artistic director" title in 2014.   Wintour apologized for her role in sidelining Black creators in June. CEO Roger Lynch plans to lean on 1) digital video and 2) paywalls to reach profitability.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Warren Buffett, David Solomon Urge Congress to Extend PPP for Small Businesses
item.description: PPP has been criticized for fraud and not actually going to small businesses. It's a $525 billion government program intended to help small businesses keep workers on payroll. In an interview with CNBC yesterday morning, legendary investor Warren Buffett urged Congress to pass legislation to help small businesses stay afloat. Help could be on the way if Congress gets the job done.   A real-world example: This summer, American Airlines was able to raise $2.5 billion from selling bonds even as it was bleeding $58 million/day.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Christmas Markets Need a Christmas Miracle
item.description: The situation is even tougher for vendors at San Francisco's Dickens Fair, which is a historic market that requires vendors to meet certain standards of "authenticity." His experience implementing health and safety protocols at the flea market helped him open the holiday market in-person safely. Michael Berman, who created the market 16 years ago, also runs D.C.'s Eastern Market and had to adapt this spring to pandemic-era guidelines. While the Christkindlmarket in Chicago is showcasing about 50 exhibitors online (close to the number it welcomed at its in-person market), most are "hanging on for dear life," according to Kate Bleeker, director of expansion and market development.   Vendors need help Small businesses that sell at markets often depend on a handful of in-person events for the majority of their annual sales. In San Francisco, the Great Dickens Christmas Fair also canceled its in-person market and set up the Dickens Fair at Home with an online shop and virtual experiences.   At Bryant Park, foot traffic and sales are estimated at a third of previous years’ levels, and Vagianos said vendors are worried."    But this year, the markets in D.C., San Francisco, and NYC currently have anywhere from a third to half the typical number of vendors exhibiting.   After watching in-person events get postponed the start of the pandemic and reconstitute on Zoom over the summer, Christmas markets began having tough conversations—and we're not talking about the final design for the collectible 2020 candle holder.   Other markets decided to open...
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: EU Unveils Regulations Targeting Big Tech
item.description: The walls are closing in This week, the FTC ordered top U.S. tech companies to explain their user data practices, China fined its own tech leaders Alibaba and Tencent over antitrust violations, and the UK proposed fines of up to 10% of global revenue if tech giants don't remove illegal content.

In an interview with CNBC yesterday morning, legendary investor Warren Buffett urged Congress to pass legislation to help small businesses stay afloat. item.title: President-elect Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
item.description: Buttigieg endorsed Biden and helped him raise money, despite Biden having run an ad mocking Buttigieg's relatively paltry experience.     More broadly, Buttigieg will manage a nearly $90 billion budget, plus oversee the agencies that regulate railroads, trucking, and aviation.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Amazon Owned Zoox Unveils Autonomous Robotaxi
item.description: It’s fast(ish): Topping out at 75 mph, it’s the speediest robotaxi in the industry. But for now, Zoox is 100% focused on people, not packages. “In a nutshell, we want to eventually move people around a city,” CEO Aicha Evans told journalist Kara Swisher in an interview.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Pornhub Bows to Pressure, Deletes Unverified Videos
item.description: Mastercard and Visa, which process payments on the site, launched an investigation.   But that wasn’t enough.   That piece set off a chain of events that have “left the porn industry shaken,” according to Motherboard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Assessing the Fallout from the SolarWinds Hack
item.description: As for the identity of the hackers, multiple outlets say all signs point to a specific group of Russian state-backed hackers called “APT29” or “Cozy Bear.”   The backstory: Hackers infiltrated the IT systems of several federal agencies and top corporations via a product made by software company SolarWinds.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: U.S. Healthcare Workers Receive First Covid Vaccines
item.description: More than 300,000 Americans have died from Covid-19. Three million more doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine will be delivered across the country this week.     Yesterday, NYC’s mayor told the city to prepare for a potential “full shutdown.” The longer process has drawn criticism from some European leaders.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Exxon Mobil Pledges Emission Cuts
item.description: Looking ahead…while fossil fuel companies struggle, a new guard of clean energy giants is beating them to investor dollars and ushering in energy’s “NextEra.”   While some are making efforts, including net-zero emissions targets and diversifying into renewables, “there doesn't seem to be an oil major that's got it all figured out between the pandemic, cloudy demand and price outlooks, and the unknown path through a world getting a bit more serious about climate,” Axios writes. Reduce overall emissions intensity by 15%–20% Halve methane emission intensity Emission “intensity”?
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Exxon Mobil Pledges Emission Cuts
item.description: Looking ahead…while fossil fuel companies struggle, a new guard of clean energy giants is beating them to investor dollars and ushering in energy’s “NextEra.”   While some are making efforts, including net-zero emissions targets and diversifying into renewables, “there doesn't seem to be an oil major that's got it all figured out between the pandemic, cloudy demand and price outlooks, and the unknown path through a world getting a bit more serious about climate,” Axios writes. He’s pledged to rejoin the Paris Accord on Day 1, invest $2 trillion in clean energy, and get the U.S. on a path to net-zero carbon emissions “no later than 2050.”
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: U.S. Healthcare Workers Receive First Covid Vaccines
item.description: More than 300,000 Americans have died from Covid-19. Three million more doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s vaccine will be delivered across the country this week.     Yesterday, NYC’s mayor told the city to prepare for a potential “full shutdown.” The longer process has drawn criticism from some European leaders.

item.title: Pornhub Bows to Pressure, Deletes Unverified Videos
item.description: Mastercard and Visa, which process payments on the site, launched an investigation.   But that wasn’t enough.   That piece set off a chain of events that have “left the porn industry shaken,” according to Motherboard.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Taking a Look at the Fallout from the SolarWinds Hack
item.description: The hack was first identified last week by FireEye, a cybersecurity company that itself was hacked.   As for the identity of the hackers, multiple outlets say all signs point to a specific group of Russian state-backed hackers called “APT29” or “Cozy Bear.”
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Week Ahead: Tesla's Grand Entrance and Another Vaccine
item.description: Everything else: Christopher Nolan's Tenet will be released digitally on Tuesday.    Tesla gets promoted: On Friday, Elon Musk's $578 billion electric automaker will join the S&P 500 index. Friday is National Ugly Sweater Day. A major snowstorm could hit the East Coast mid-week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Kevin From 'The Office' Will Bring in More Than $1 Million on Cameo This Year
item.description: But Galanis thinks President Trump would crush Dobrik if he joined Cameo. Since he charges $195/video, we estimate Baumgartner will have averaged at least 14 videos per day in 2020.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Roblox, Affirm Delay IPOs to Early 2021
item.description: And even companies that make no money are soaring: At least three electric vehicle companies worth more than $2 billion have no revenue. Recent IPO trends may lead them to sell more shares or price them differently. Affirm and Roblox were hoping for valuations as high as $10 billion and $8 billion, respectively.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: George Senate Races Attracting Attention from Corporate America
item.description: the vote is scheduled for Jan. 5, but in-person early voting starts today. Looking ahead... Its online fundraising platform processed nearly $112 million in donations from Nov. 4 to Nov. 23 (the GOP equivalent processed $55.6 million).
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The First Covid-19 Vaccines Are Being Delivered
item.description: Altogether, around 3 million doses will snake their way to 636 distribution centers across the country in the coming days.   The vaccine requires two shots a month apart, so officials are saving the second half of the ~6.4 million doses planned for the first wave to send out in a few weeks.   Supply chain: In 2009, delivery timetables for the swine flu vaccine shifted regularly. It's expected to get approval. The remaining challenges Spoilage: Pfizer's vaccine needs to maintain -94°F, and although the company has equipped shipping containers with dry ice and GPS-enabled temperature sensors, it's expected that some doses won't survive the journey.
item.author: Alex Hickey
